title: MAS to ease rules on finance companies to help SMEs obtain funds
text:
Singapore MAS to ease rules on finance companies to help SMEs obtain funds With the regulatory changes, which will be implemented in phases starting from this year, SMEs will have more access to financing even if they are unable to offer collateral and business customers will be able to contract more conveniently. Posted 14 Feb 2017 09:08 Updated 14 Feb 2017 09:10 Office workers walk to the train station during evening rush hour in the financial district of Singapore on Mar 9, 2015. (File photo: Reuters/Edgar Su) A 
SINGAPORE: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced on Tuesday (Feb 14) it will relax some business restrictions on finance companies to help small and medium size enterprises (SMEs) obtain financing. 
Currently, there are three finance companies - Hong Leong Finance, Sing Investments and Finance and Singapore Finance - licensed by MAS to take deposits and loans. They have combined assets of S$16 billion and accounted for just under S$7 billion in outstanding loans to SMEs in the second quarter of last year. 
In a statement, MAS said it would be relaxing some of the business restrictions that currently apply to them in order to enhance their role in SME financing. 
The limit for aggregate uncollateralised lending will be raised to up to 25 per cent of the finance companies' capital funds, from the current cap of 10 per cent. 
The aggregate limit for uncollateralised lending to a single borrower will also be raised to up to 0.5 per cent of the capital funds of the finance company, up from the current cap of S$5,000. 
These changes will better enable finance companies to serve their SME customers, many of whom require unsecured credit for working capital needs, the central bank said. 
In order to allow them to provide more comprehensive credit and deposit services to SMEs, finance companies will also be allowed to offer current accounts and chequing services to business customers, as well as join electronic payment networks like Interbank GIRO, Fast and secure transfers (FAST) and Secure Transfers and Electronic Funds Transfer at Point of Sale. 
To safeguard prudential standards, the central bank says it will require these companies to enhance their corporate governance and risk management, including imposing stricter rules on related party transactions and limits on exposures to the property sector. 
The regulatory changes will be implemented in phases starting this year. 
LIBERALISATION OF FOREIGN TAKEOVER POLICY 
In addition, MAS said in the statement that it will liberalise its existing policy of not allowing foreign takeovers of finance companies. 
It is prepared to consider an application for a merger and acquisition if the prospective merger partner or acquirer commits to maintaining SME financing as a core business of the finance company, demonstrates expertise in SME financing and presents proposals to enhance the finance company's SME lending activities with new technologies, methodologies or business models, it said. 
MAS deputy managing director Ong Chong Tee said that the changes will facilitate finance companies' efforts to invest in new capabilities to enhance their core SME financing businesses. 
These are part of the central bank's "ongoing efforts to ensure that our financial sector continues to be able to support enterprise development", he added. - CNA
